questions.question: Question 1: Ptyalin is secreted by which of the following glands?
questions.explanation:
Ptyalin (salivary  -amylase) is secreted by the salivary gland. There are 3 pairs of salivary glands • Parotid • Submandibular • Sublingual glands Functions of saliva: 564 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following statements is false?

options.a: Meissner’s plexus is present in submucosa
options.b: Myentric plexus is present between inner circular and outer longitudinal muscle layer
options.c: Muscularis mucosa is associated with peristalsis
options.d: Villi are absent in large intestine

questions.explanation:
Muscularis propria is associated with peristalsis and not muscularis mucosa. Contraction of muscularis mucosa alters absorptive and secretive surface area. Meissner’s plexus (submucosal plexus) is present in the submucosa. The myenteric plexus (Auerbach plexus) is present between the inner circular and outer 
longitudinal muscle layer. Villi are absent in the large intestine but present in the small intestine. Layers of intestinal wall from outside to inside are as follows: • Serosa • The longitudinal smooth muscle layer • The circular smooth muscle layer • Submucosa • Mucosa 565 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 3: Salivary amylase is inactivated by which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Salivary amylase is inactivated by the low pH of the stomach. It is rapidly denatured at pH 4 
(gastric pH is 1 to 3.5). Salivary amylase is activated by chloride. Salivary  amylase (Ptyalin): • Digests starch: cleaves internal  -1,4-glycosidic bonds in starch • Optimum pH: 7 • Denatured at pH 4 Since a large portion of a meal often remains unmixed for a considerable length of time in the 
stomach, the salivary enzyme may account for the digestion of as much as 75% of the starch 
present before it is denatured by gastric acid. Note: Even in the absence of salivary amylase, there is no defect in carbohydrate digestion 
because pancreatic amylase is sufficient to digest all of the ingested starch.

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following gland secretes lingual lipase?
questions.explanation:
Lingual lipase is secreted by von Ebner’s gland. von Ebner's gland is a serous salivary gland situated around circumvallate and foliate papillae in 
front of the terminal sulcus. Lingual lipase hydrolyse dietary lipid. The optimal pH is 3-6. Unlike pancreatic lipase, it is not 
inhibited by bile salts, medium-chain FA, and lecithin. Hence, it remains active through the 
stomach and into the intestine. 566 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following fluids have the highest daily secretion of potassium?
questions.explanation:
The highest daily secretion of K+ is into the saliva. In the process of formation of saliva, Na+ and Cl- are reabsorbed from the saliva, and K+ and 
HCO3- are secreted into the saliva. Note: The highest concentration of K+ is in the rectal fluid.

questions.question:
Question 6: The secretomotor fibers to the parotid gland causing a patient to salivate, pass through which 
of the following ganglions?
questions.explanation:
The secretomotor fibers to the parotid gland pass through the Otic ganglion. Salivary secretion is almost entirely controlled by the parasympathetic nervous system. Volume is 
mainly mediated by parasympathetic stimulation while the composition of saliva (increased 
proteinaceous content) is slightly modified by sympathetic input. The parasympathetic preganglionic fibers are delivered by the glossopharyngeal and facial nerves 
to otic and submandibular ganglion respectively. Regulation of salivary secretion by the parasympathetic nervous system:

questions.question: Question 7: Rennin is present in
questions.explanation:
Rennin is present in the gastric juice. It is also called chymosin. It is a protein-digesting enzyme (endopeptidase) found in the stomach of newborn cows. It 
transforms (curdles) caseinogen into insoluble casein. In humans and in some animals that lack rennin, milk is coagulated by the action of pepsin. 567 
Sold by @itachibot Note: Renin is produced by juxtaglomerular cells of the kidney, which hydrolyzes angiotensinogen 
to angiotensin I.

questions.question:
Question 8: A patient presents with anemia and achlorhydria. After evaluation, pernicious anemia is 
diagnosed. Damage to which of the following cells is responsible for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Pernicious anemia develops due to autoimmune damage to the parietal cells in gastric glands. The parietal cells secrete both HCl and intrinsic factor. Therefore, when the parietal cells are 
destroyed, both achlorhydria, as well as pernicious anemia, develop. Pernicious anemia occurs due to the deficiency of the intrinsic factor of Castle, which is important 
for the absorption of vitamin B12.

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following is secreted by the Goblet cells?
questions.explanation:
Goblet cells secrete mucus. These cells are located on the surface of the crypts of Lieberkuhn 
and the villi of the small intestine. Cells present in the crypts of Lieberkuhn: • Goblet cells (similar to surface cells of the stomach) - secrete mucus that acts as a lubricant and 
protects the intestinal surface • Epithelial cells - secrete succus entericus (intestinal secretion) • Paneth cells - secrete lysozymes and defensins (antibacterial substances)

questions.question: Question 10: In the stomach, H+ ions are secreted in exchange for which of the following ions?
questions.explanation:
H+ ions are secreted into the lumen of the stomach in exchange for K+ by the H+–K+ pump (H+, 
K+-ATPase). Mechanism of HCl formation: • In the parietal cells, CO2 and H2O are converted to H+ and HCO3–, catalyzed by carbonic 
anhydrase. • H+ is secreted into the lumen of the stomach by the H+–K+ pump in exchange for K+. • HCO3– moves out of the cell into the bloodstream in exchange for Cl– (Cl––HCO3–exchange). 
This Cl– moves into the lumen of the stomach. • H+ and Cl– combine to form HCl. 568 
Sold by @itachibot As HCO3– is added to the venous blood, the pH of the blood increases. This is called alkaline 
tide. Eventually, this HCO3– will be secreted in the pancreatic secretions to neutralize H+ in the 
small intestine. Proton pump inhibitors inhibit H+–K+ pump.

questions.question:
Question 11: A patient diagnosed with gastroesophageal reflux disease is found to have excess gastric 
secretion. All of the following are likely to increase the secretion, except:
questions.explanation:
Gastric secretion is not increased by HCl. HCl decreases gastric secretion via a negative feedback 
mechanism. Low pH due to HCl in the stomach inhibits gastrin secretion, which in turn, inhibits H+ secretion. 
Hence, the presence of HCl inhibits gastric secretion. Stimuli that increase acid and gastrin secretion: • Distension of stomach • Peptides • Calcium • Alcohol and caffeine • Increased vagal discharge Stimuli that decrease acid and gastrin secretion: • Gastric acid • Secretin family - secretin, glucagon, VIP, GIP • Somatostatin • CCK, Calcitonin • PGE2 569 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 12: A patient with recurrent abdominal pain is found to have multiple duodenal ulcers. After a 
detailed evaluation, he is diagnosed with Zollinger-Ellison syndrome. Stimulation of which of 
the following can inhibit gastric secretion in this patient? 558 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Gastric secretion is inhibited by somatostatin. It inhibits gastric secretion via both direct and indirect pathways: • Direct pathway - somatostatin acts directly on the acid-producing parietal cells by binding to 
receptors on parietal cells that are coupled to adenylyl cyclase via a Gi protein. This inhibits 
adenylyl cyclase, and cAMP levels are reduced. In this way, somatostatin antagonizes the 
stimulatory effect of histamine on H+ secretion. • Indirect pathway - somatostatin inhibits the release of histamine and gastrin and thus 
decreasing H+ secretion indirectly.

questions.question: Question 13: Maximum gastric secretion occurs in which of the following phases?

options.d: Secretion is equal in all phases

questions.explanation: Maximum gastric secretion occurs in the gastric phase.

questions.question: Question 14: Which of the following is responsible for increasing the HCl secretion in the gastric phase?
questions.explanation:
HCl secretion in the gastric phase is increased by gastrin. Gastrin stimulates H+ secretion by interaction with cholecystokinin B (CCKB) receptor on the 
parietal cell which secretes HCl. 570 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following is true about the secretion from the exocrine pancreas?
questions.explanation:
Pancreatic secretion is stimulated by cholecystokinin (CCK) and Ach. It is always isotonic. It has virtually the same Na+ and K+ concentrations as in plasma. It is rich in several digestive 
enzymes like amylase, trypsin, chymotrypsin, lipase, elastase, etc.

questions.question:
Question 16: Bicarbonate-rich pancreatic juice is secreted under the influence of which of the following 
stimulants? 559 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Bicarbonate-rich pancreatic juice is secreted under the influence of secretin. Secretin is secreted by the S cells of the duodenum. Its primary function is to promote the 
secretion of bicarbonate-rich pancreatic juice by the ductal cells of the pancreas and duodenum. 
This secretion is poor in enzymes. Other functions: • Augments the effects of CCK • Inhibits gastrin release • Decreases gastric acid secretion • Contraction of the pyloric sphincter • Exerts trophic effect on the pancreas

questions.question: Question 17: Which among the following is the most alkaline secretion?
questions.explanation:
The most alkaline secretion is Brunner’s gland secretion with a pH of 8.0 – 8.9. 571 
Sold by @itachibot Brunner’s gland is located in the first few centimeters of the duodenal wall. It secretes large 
amounts of alkaline mucus in response to tactile stimuli on the duodenal mucosa, vagal 
stimulation, and GI hormones, especially secretin. It is inhibited by sympathetic stimulation. The function of the mucus secreted by Brunner’s glands is to protect the duodenal wall from 
digestion by the highly acidic gastric juice emptying from the stomach. Note: The second most alkaline secretion in the GI tract is the pancreatic juice.

questions.question: Question 18: Which of the following is the most potent choleretic?
questions.explanation:
Bile salts (chemical choleretic) are the most potent choleretics. Any substance that increases bile secretion is called a choleretic. Bile secretion may be increased 
by chemical (bile salts), hormonal (Secretin), and neural (vagal stimulation) mechanisms. Note: Cholagogues cause contraction of the gallbladder. Eg. CCK

questions.question: Question 19: Primary bile acids are synthesized from
questions.explanation:
Primary bile acids are synthesized from cholesterol by hepatocytes. Bile contains bile acids, bile salts, bile pigments, phospholipids, water, and electrolytes. It is 
secreted by the liver and concentrated in the gall bladder. Two primary bile acids (cholic acid and chenodeoxycholic acid) are synthesized from cholesterol 
by hepatocytes. When these primary bile acids are secreted into the lumen of the intestine, a 
portion of each is converted to secondary bile acids (deoxycholic acid and lithocholic acid) by 
bacteria. The liver conjugates primary and secondary bile acids with glycine or taurine to their respective 
bile salts. Ex: Glycocholic acid, Taurodeoxycholic acid. Rate of bile secretion is 30 - 60 mL/hour (500 - 1000 mL/day). Note: Bile has no digestive enzymes.

questions.question: Question 20: Enterohepatic circulation is necessary for the secretion of
questions.explanation:
Enterohepatic circulation is necessary for the secretion of bile salts. The enterohepatic circulation of bile salts is the recycling of bile salts between the small intestine 
(terminal ileum) and the liver by means of the portal vein. It occurs 6-8 times a day. The recirculation of bile salts to the liver reduces the demand to synthesize new bile salts. 572 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 21: Which of the following does not belong to the secretin family?
questions.explanation: CCK (Cholecystokinin) belongs to the gastrin family, not the secretin family. Classification of GI hormones based on structure and function: • Gastrin family - Gastrin, Cholecystokinin • Secretin family - Secretin, Glucagon, VIP, GIP • Others - Motilin, Ghrelin, Somatostatin, etc

questions.question:
Question 22: A patient underwent resection of the gastric antrum. A few weeks later, endoscopy revealed 
atrophy of the gastric mucosa. Serum levels of gastrin were found to be decreased. Which of 
the following is true regarding this GI hormone?
questions.explanation:
Gastrin is a peptide hormone. It is secreted by the G cells of the gastric mucosa present in the antrum of the stomach, primarily 
during the gastric phase of gastric acid secretion. It causes gastric secretion at 1000-1500 mL/day. Its primary stimulus is gastric distension. Primary functions of Gastrin: • Gastric acid (HCl) secretion • Pepsin secretion • Trophic action on the gastric mucosa Other functions: • Stimulates gastric motility • Prevents gastroesophageal reflux by contraction of LES 573 
Sold by @itachibot Conditions associated with increased gastrin secretions (Ex: Zollinger-Ellison syndrome), will 
cause an increase in H+ secretion and hypertrophy of the gastric mucosa. Conditions associated with reduced gastrin secretion (Ex: Resection of the gastric antrum), will 
cause a decrease in H+ secretion and atrophy of the gastric mucosa.

questions.question: Question 23: What is the effect of cholecystokinin on GIT?
questions.explanation:
Cholecystokinin (CCK) inhibits gastric emptying. It is secreted by the I cells of the duodenal and jejunal mucosa in response to monoglycerides, 
fatty acids, and amino acids. Primary functions: • Stimulation of pancreatic enzyme secretion • Contraction of the gallbladder • Relaxation of the sphincter of Oddi Other functions: • Augmentation of the action of secretin in producing alkaline (bicarbonate rich) pancreatic juice • Inhibition of gastric emptying • Trophic (growth) effect on the exocrine pancreas • Increases the synthesis of enterokinase • It enhances the motility of the small intestine and colon • Along with secretin, it augments the contraction of the pyloric sphincter and thus preventing the 
reflux of duodenal contents into the stomach • It promotes satiety

questions.question:
Question 24: What stimulates secretin secretion? 561 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Secretin secretion is stimulated by acid. Stimuli that increase secretin secretion: • Low duodenal pH (2-4.5) due to acid in the chyme • Products of protein digestion in the upper small intestine Secretin secretion is regulated by negative feedback: 574 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 25: Liver synthesizes all of the following except:
questions.explanation: Immunoglobulins are not synthesized by the liver. They are produced by plasma cells. Plasma proteins synthesized by the liver are: • Albumin • Coagulation/clotting factors • Acute-phase proteins • Steroid binding and other hormone-binding proteins

questions.question: Question 26: How much is the daily secretion of gastric juice?
questions.explanation:
Daily secretion of gastric juice is between 1500-2000 mL. Note: This is a controversial question- Daily secretion of gastric juice is • 1500 mL according to Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology,13th edition, Page no: 
819 • 2500 mL according to Ganong's Review Of Medical Physiology - 25th Edition, Page no:464 Choose 2500 mL if given in the options. If not, choose within the range of 1500-2500 mL.

questions.question: Question 27: Which of the following statement is correct regarding secretin?
questions.explanation:
Secretin increases HCO3- secretion by ductal cells of the pancreas and duodenum. It is secreted by the S cells in the upper small intestine. 575 
Sold by @itachibot Functions of secretion are: • Primary function •  HCO3- secretion by ductal cells of pancreas and duodenum • Other functions • Augments the effects of CCK • Inhibits gastrin release •  gastric acid secretion • Contraction of pyloric sphincter • Exerts trophic effect on the pancreas

questions.question: Question 28: Which of the following is secreted by the I cells of duodenum?
questions.explanation: I cells of the duodenum secrete CCK.

questions.question:
Question 29: A 40-year-old man presented with abdominal pain and diarrhea. On investigations, multiple 
ulcers were seen in the proximal and distal duodenum and in the jejunum. The gastric pH 
was found to be 1.2 with a serum gastrin concentration of 2000 pg/ml. Which of the following 
is the primary site for the production of GI hormone raised in this patient?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Zollinger-Ellison syndrome. In this condition, serum 
gastrin concentration is raised to around >1000 pg/ml. Gastrin is primarily secreted by G cells 
present in the antrum of the stomach.

questions.question: Question 30: Which of the following hormones do not act on the pancreas?

options.a: Fructose is absorbed in the intestine by secondary active transport
options.b: SGLT2 is involved in absorption of monosaccharide in intestine
options.c: GLUT2 is involved in transport of glucose from enterocyte into interstitium

questions.explanation:
Gastrin does not act upon the pancreas. Gastrin stimulates gastric acid secretion and gastric 
mucosal growth. GI hormones acting on the pancreas include: GIP is also known as Glucose-dependent insulinotropic peptide. CCK(Cholecystokinin) 
Secretin 
GIP(Gastric inhibitory peptid
